DOC.HEAD: $adv31
AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
For Release Sunday, Dec. 31
From AP Newsfeatures
(APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 5 b&w photos.)
DOC.TEXT: Come take a ride on a New York subway with a conductor who likes to entertain his passengers with funny announcements at each station stop. Harry Nugent, the son of a circus barker, says he wants o reassure the riders that they haven't left civilization behind when they walk down the subway stairs.

The No. 1 Broadway local is packed, but the subway can't leave the station. It can't leave the station because the train's doors can't close. The doors can't close because some idiot is holding them open for a late arrival on the platform. This is bad enough, but the passengers must now brace for an accompanying sonic assault _ the obligatory conductor's admonition over the public address system, always delivered in harsh, loud New Yawkese: ``STANCLEARADACLOSINDOORS.'' But instead, this morning they are surprised to hear: ``Your heart's in the right place, but your foot isn't. If you don't want to ride, just step onto the platform. You'll find it's quite stationary.'' This message is delivered not as a rebuke, but as a gentle reminder, and the speaker's voice is smooth and soothing, like that of a professional broadcaster from the old school. The impression _ and the hope _ that this will not be the usual subway trip is confirmed at the next stop. ``This is Rector Street, well-positioned in the financial district. Rub shoulders with the Stock Exchangers, but stand clear of the closing doors. This is the No. 1 to Van Cortlandt Park.'' The conductor is Harry Nugent, who has raised station-stop announcements to an art and introduced a measure of civility into a subterranean realm that could use it. Nugent, 60, is a pleasant man with a neat moustache and receding hairline who manages to look natty in the standard blue Transit Authority uniform and cap. Imaginative announcements break the tedium, he explains. But he also wants passengers to feel they haven't left civilization merely by walking down a flight of stairs. ``This is Franklin Street, TriBeCa in location, litigious in concept and convenient to an eclectic collection of courthouses. Franklin will be followed by Canal as we make our way to Van Cortlandt Park.'' How did a guy who talks like this get into subway conducting? Nugent says he spent 15 years at Look magazine ``basically as a gofer with a nice office on the 16th floor.'' When the magazine folded he became a conductor because, he says with a smile, ``I didn't want to get out of communications.'' Then he adds: ``It was a port in a storm.'' That was 17 years ago. ``Now we're entering 14th Street Station. If you think you'd like to change into something else, you can slip into a 2 or a 3 train. Speaking of numbers, we're the 1 to Van Cortlandt Park.'' Before leaving the train, a middle-aged man carrying a briefcase walks up to Nugent and tells him, ``If the rest of the Transit Authority was as competent as you, they'd have no problems.'' A well-dressed woman asks Nugent for his name, which she writes down in a notebook. She seems reluctant to get off at her stop. ``We're approaching 23rd Street, which puts its best foot forward with the illustrious Chelsea Hotel. Its other foot isn't bad either _ the Flatiron Building. The next stop we encounter will be 28th Street.'' Nugent says he began to embellish his announcements about eight years ago, when the Transit Authority was trying to get conductors to give passengers more information _ a process that was abetted by the arrival of new trains with audible public address systems. Nugent had spent a lot of time between stops thinking about what to say. ``At first I just wanted to break the hostility with a few elegant announcements. But the point I'm at now is probably absurd. Maybe I've been breathing too much steel dust down here.'' ``Our stop is 28th Street, noted for its flora and fauna. It's the site of the flower district and the fur district. Twenty-eighth will be followed by 33rd. That's the way it is on the No. 1 local.'' Perhaps the steel dust is taking effect.
